title: The End of Small-Town America, in the Heart of Seoul
text:
SEOUL—The U.S. military’s downtown Seoul home is an American oasis on its last legs. Rusted goal posts overlook a closed high school. The front lawns of identical ranch-style houses have turned brown. The narrow sidewalks, just wide enough for two people, have started to crack.

“I’m seeing the death of a hometown,” said John Nowell, a 77-year-old retired U.S. soldier who moved to Yongsan in 1965, when there were still ox carts winding through the streets of Seoul.

By year’s end, nearly all of the more than 20,000 U.S. troops and family members will have vacated the barracks inside Yongsan Garrison. They are relocating to the new $11 billion Camp Humphreys, America’s largest overseas military base, about 40 miles south of Seoul.

As South Korea says farewell to Yongsan, the Korean Peninsula still finds itself confronting the type of military unrest that justified a massive U.S. presence following the 1950-1953 Korean War.

A peace treaty, formally ending that war, remains unsigned. Pyongyang continues to engage in provocations, including a spree of short-range missiles tests last month. The U.S. and South Korea recently concluded drills meant to hone their readiness against a sudden attack from Pyongyang. Nuclear negotiations with the North remain gridlocked.

Yongsan, the U.S. military garrison in the South Korean capital, in June. The facility is closing and the Americans stationed there are relocating to the new Camp Humphreys, south of Seoul. Photo: Clément Bürge/The Wall Street Journal

The closure of Yongsan—which means dragon hill—marks the end of an era for a slice of small-town Americana in the heart of South Korea’s capital. The move to Camp Humphreys consolidates what had been multiple U.S. camps at a single site and pushes American forces farther from the firing range of North Korea’s artillery.

Some of those who will stay behind are already reeling from the transition.

At the Grand Ole Opry, a country-music bar near Yongsan, a Theodore Roosevelt painting hangs on the wall along with a Confederate flag smothered with U.S. dollar bills. “I’ve lost a lot of my regular customers,” said owner Kim Sam-sook, a 78-year-old widow of an American who fought in the Korean War. She fears the establishment may have to close.

Long South Korea’s epicenter for Western culture, the local neighborhood surrounding Yongsan, which catered to U.S. soldiers, carried a seedy reputation. It was once home to a flourishing black market of U.S. military goods, such as mayonnaise, smuggled off base, and brothels frequented by American soldiers.

The area has cleaned up though, as South Korea’s economy boomed and brought more prosperity and international acceptance. Yongsan saw its monopoly on Taco Bell burritos, Super Bowl parties and Dr. Seuss books fade.

Yongsan, roughly two-thirds the size of New York’s Central Park, is now surrounded by high-rise apartments and glistening corporate headquarters. Blocks away from the U.S. base, diners can choose between local branches of The Halal Guys or The Original Pancake House.

But as one piece of America sinks into South Korea's history books, another is rising—literally.

Camp Humphreys, in the quiet coastal town of Pyeongtaek, famous for its pears and cucumbers, is almost seven times the size of Yongsan. The transition required a geological makeover of what had been a smaller U.S. outpost. The land on the base was raised by 8.5 feet to prevent flooding. Nearly 1,000 miles of telecom cable—about the distance from New York to St. Louis—was inserted. The base’s population is expected to soon surpass 40,000.

Nearly all of the more than 20,000 U.S. troops and their families stationed at Seoul's Yongsan Garrison will have vacated by the end of the year. Photo: Clément Bürge/The Wall Street Journal

“The goal is to recreate what we had in Yongsan,” said Army Colonel Scott Taylor, a senior officer serving at Camp Humphreys.

The base boasts new 12-story apartment blocks, barbecue grills and baseball diamonds. At one of five malls, people can shop for vitamins at a GNC store or buy hiking books at a Timberland. Uniformed soldiers wolf down Philly cheesesteaks at Charleys or General Tso’s chicken from Manchu Wok.

The relocation has been a welcome development for an alliance that has been troubled of late. Seoul’s recent cancellation of an intelligence pact with Tokyo irked Washington, which viewed the move as hurting the U.S.’s ability to deter Pyongyang, Beijing and Moscow in the region. President Trump has repeatedly called for South Korea to pay more for hosting U.S. troops.

Still, more than two-thirds of South Koreans support a U.S. military presence in the future, polls say. Americans who have served in the country consider it a second home.

While Yongsan will return to South Korea as early as next year, a small portion will remain American: the U.S. Embassy in Seoul plans to relocate there. When it does, the holdovers will be the diplomatic housing and the military-owned Dragon Hill Lodge—where the hotel restaurant serves Maine lobsters and diners can pay with U.S. cash.

The new $11 billion Camp Humphreys, America’s largest overseas military base, about 40 miles south of Seoul. The base’s population is expected to soon surpass 40,000. Photo: Clément Bürge/The Wall Street Journal

Meanwhile, South Koreans are debating what to do with the rest of Yongsan, which has remained in Japanese or U.S. hands for 115 years. Some local residents argue Yongsan’s central location makes it prime real estate for affordable homes, but government officials have other ideas.

“It will be reborn as Yongsan Park,” said Kim Hyun-mee, who heads the South Korean ministry overseeing land, infrastructure and transport, at a media event last year. The proposal for the park includes a lake and brand new subway lines below the Yongsan Garrison site.

After more than five decades in Yongsan, Mr. Nowell, the retired U.S. soldier, likens the closure to the death of a small American factory town. “Well, it’s a bygone era. No more,” he said.

Write to Andrew Jeong at andrew.jeong@wsj.com
